title: Ticket #823: Log rotation problem at 2GB boundary
description:
Setting max log size such as MAX_SCHEDD_LOG = 2147483648 to reduce rotation causes problems. I believe it may be due to int in condor_util_lib/dprintf.c

int MaxLog[D_NUMLEVELS+1] = { 0 };
remarks:
updated to us condor_sys_types.h uint64_t

2010-Jan-29 10:48:32 by psilord:
This change only affects Condor's ability to rotate a log file if its size is 2GB or greater. Due to the param() parsing code's inability at this time to read an integer larger than INT_MAX (it passes the textual integer string from the config file to atoi()!), Condor can't actually be made to produce a log file larger than 2GB either on 32 or 64 bit machines. This hopefully will be fixed in the future.

2010-Jan-29 10:58:53 by psilord:
Speaking of, if param() does use atoi(), which it does, cause I just looked, then using that value for the max schedd log will result in a hilarious value. as this code demonstrates: 

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int main(void)
{
    char *intmax = "2147483647";
    char *intmaxp1 = "2147483648";

    printf("int max = %d\n", atoi(intmax));
    printf("int max + 1 = %d\n", atoi(intmaxp1));

    return 0;
}

When you run it, you get this: 

Linux nmi-s006 > ./a.out
int max = 2147483647
int max + 1 = -2147483648
Linux nmi-s006 >

That looks very wrong. Here's why: 

/usr/include/limits.h:#  define INT_MIN (-INT_MAX - 1)
/usr/include/limits.h:#  define INT_MAX 2147483647

Hence, I don't think the original implementor fully understood the problem or the fix.

2010-Jan-29 11:09:48 by psilord:
Now, suppose we do this: 

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <inttypes.h>

int main(void)
{
    char *intmax = "2147483647";
    char *intmaxp1 = "2147483648";
    char *intmaxp2 = "2147483649";
    uint64_t val;

    printf("int max = %d\n", atoi(intmax));
    printf("int max + 1 = %d\n", atoi(intmaxp1));

    val = atoi(intmaxp1);
    printf("uint64_t max + 1 = %lu\n", atoi(intmaxp1));

    val = atoi(intmaxp2);
    printf("uint64_t max + 2 = %lu\n", atoi(intmaxp2));

    return 0;
}

Then you get an answer like this: 

Linux nmi-s006 > ./a.out
int max = 2147483647
int max + 1 = -2147483648
uint64_t max + 1 = 2147483648
uint64_t max + 2 = 2147483649

Which while it appears to give the right answer, it does for completely non-intuitive reasons due to two's complement behavior of negative numbers when assigned to unsigned quantities.

2010-Jan-29 11:17:06 by psilord:
It looks like the main deal with this issue is that we're trying to squeeze an unsigned int 32-bit quantity out of atoi() via tricks with assignment to a larger unsigned type. At best, if this trick were propagated to everywhere which uses said value, the log files could reach a 4GB range, but forever more be modulo 4GB since at that point in time we've counted every value atoi() could give us. So, uint64_t is actually a lie, since we can't ever see anything larger than 4GB from atoi() using any trick.

The real fix would be to stop using atoi() to get back our values from param() and upconvert the general integral type param() returns to int64_t.

diff -ruHp condor-7.4.0.orig/src/condor_util_lib/dprintf.c condor-7.4.0/src/condor_util_lib/dprintf.c
--- condor-7.4.0.orig/src/condor_util_lib/dprintf.c	2010-02-10 13:04:30.000000000 -0500
+++ condor-7.4.0/src/condor_util_lib/dprintf.c	2010-03-01 11:09:16.000000000 -0500
@@ -560,8 +560,8 @@ debug_lock(int debug_level)
 				// Probably format should be %ld, and we should cast to
 				// long int, but I'm afraid of changing the output format.
 				// wenger 2009-02-24.
-			fprintf( DebugFP, "MaxLog = %d, length = %d\n",
-					 MaxLog[debug_level], (int)length );
+			fprintf( DebugFP, "MaxLog = %u, length = %u\n",
+					 MaxLog[debug_level], length );
 			preserve_log_file(debug_level);
 		}
 	}
diff -ruHp condor-7.4.0.orig/src/condor_util_lib/dprintf_config.c condor-7.4.0/src/condor_util_lib/dprintf_config.c

 extern char		*DebugFile[D_NUMLEVELS+1];

 extern char		*_condor_DebugFlagNames[];
@@ -204,7 +204,7 @@ dprintf_config( const char *subsys )
 				}
 				pval = param(pname);
 				if( pval != NULL ) {
-					MaxLog[debug_level] = atoi( pval );
+					MaxLog[debug_level] = atol( pval );
 					free(pval);
 				} else {
